SUMMARY: phenylacetic acid regulator [9748275] PaaX, is a transcriptional repressor that participates in controlling transcriptional regulation of genes involved in catabolism of an aromatic compound, phenylacetic acid (PA) [10766858]. When PaaX is overexpressed, it causes elevated levels of mutations in genome; refore, it is a candidate to regulate DNA replication, recombination, or repair [15225322]. PaaX contains a helix-turn-helix motif for DNA binding that is similar to motif found in N terminal of members of GntR family of transcriptional regulators [9748275]. Members of this family share similar N-terminal DNA-binding domains but are classified into four subfamilies according to ir divergence in ir C-terminal domains, which are involved in effector binding and oligomerization [11756427]. Homology with PaaX has been found in or bacteria, such as Pseudomonas putida, Bacillus halodurans, and Arthrobacter sp., among ors [10766858]. majority of work concerning PaaX has been done in E. coli W, in which has been found DNA-binding sites for PaaX, including a site upstream of paaXY operon [15159386]. DNA-binding consensus of PaaX consists of a palindromic sequence of 6 bp separated by about 27 bp [15159386, 16788190]. This palindromic property of PaaX site as well as presence of a helix-turn helix motif in protein have been basis for suggestions that PaaX binds DNA as a dimer [10766858, 15159386]. binding of PaaX to DNA is inhibited by phenylacetyl-CoA, which is product of first catabolic step in PA degradation [10766858, 9748275]. paaX is transcribed in an operon (paaXY) that is located in genome downstream and in same orientation as paaABCDEFGHIJK operon, which is repressed by PaaX [10766858]. Crystal structures of transcriptional repressor PaaX have been determined [22102047].
